Is the left column a C–E–G triad in close position on the treble staff with C as the bass note on the bass staff (root position)?
Is the middle column a C–E–G triad in close position on the treble staff with E as the bass note on the bass staff (first inversion)?
Is the right column a C–E–G triad in close position on the treble staff with G as the bass note on the bass staff (second inversion)?
Are the treble triads spelled only with the natural pitch classes C, E, and G (no accidentals)?
Are the bass notes vertically aligned under their corresponding treble triads in each column?

prompt: On a single treble-clef staff with no key or time signature, notate the interval of a perfect 11th above middle C using whole notes. Place the lower pitch as middle C (C4) on a single ledger line below the staff, and the upper pitch as F (F5) on the top line of the treble staff. Do not add stems or additional symbols.

scoring_points.question: Is a treble clef shown on a single staff?
Is the lower note placed as middle C on one ledger line below the treble staff?
Is the upper note placed on the top line of the treble staff corresponding to F?
Do the two notes form a perfect 11th (C up to F, an octave plus a fourth)?
Are both notes notated as whole notes (semibreves) without stems?
Are the two notes notated on the same treble staff with no extra markings (no key or time signature, dynamics, or other symbols)?

prompt: Music theory diagram task: On a single five-line staff with a treble clef, notate a left-to-right sequence of dyads (two simultaneous notes) using whole notes to illustrate compound intervals built above the same lower pitch. Provide seven examples in order: 8ve, 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th, 13th, and 14th. Keep the lower note identical in all dyads; for each successive dyad, place the upper note a diatonic octave plus a 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th, and 7th above that lower note respectively. Space each dyad horizontally so the progression is visually clear.

scoring_points.question: Is there a single five-line staff with a treble clef?
Are there exactly seven dyads arranged from left to right?
Is the lower note the same pitch in all seven dyads?
Do the upper notes form, in order, an 8ve, 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th, 13th, and 14th above the lower note using diatonic counting?
Are the notes written as whole notes (open noteheads without stems)?
Do line/space placements of the upper notes follow correct diatonic alternation consistent with the listed compound intervals?

prompt: Create a clean, staff-less instructional table (grid with columns) for Western notation in common time (4/4). Provide five rows for rhythmic values: whole, half, quarter, eighth, sixteenth. For each row, include: (1) the correct note glyph (whole: open oval; half: open with stem; quarter: filled with stem; eighth: filled with one flag or beam; sixteenth: filled with two flags or double beam), (2) the corresponding rest glyph (whole rest hanging below a line; half rest sitting on a line; quarter rest squiggle; eighth rest with one flag; sixteenth rest with two flags), (3) the numeric beat value under 4/4 (4, 2, 1, 1/2, 1/4), and (4) a single 4/4 measure containing only that subdivision: 1 whole note, 2 half notes, 4 quarter notes, 8 eighth notes, and 16 sixteenth notes. Use conventional beaming for subdivisions (pair eighths; group sixteenths in fours).

scoring_points.question: Are there exactly five rows corresponding to whole, half, quarter, eighth, and sixteenth durations?
Are the note glyphs correct for each duration (open oval; open with stem; filled with stem; filled with one flag/beam; filled with two flags/double beam)?
Are the rest glyphs correct for each duration (whole rest hanging; half rest sitting; quarter squiggle; eighth one-flag rest; sixteenth two-flag rest)?
Are the beat values under 4/4 shown as 4, 2, 1, 1/2, and 1/4 for whole through sixteenth respectively?
Does the 4/4 measure column contain 1, 2, 4, 8, and 16 notes respectively for whole through sixteenth?
Are eighth notes beamed in pairs and sixteenth notes grouped by fours in their measure examples?
Is the information presented in a grid-like table with separate columns for note glyph, rest glyph, beat value, and 4/4 measure example?

prompt: Draw a single staff in the key of B-flat major and 4/4 time signature, with four quarter notes of the same pitch. Above each note, place a different articulation mark in the following order: staccatissimo, staccato, tenuto, and accent. Label each articulation mark with the corresponding letter a), b), c), and d) above the staff.

scoring_points.question: Is there a single staff?
Is the key signature exactly two flats (B-flat and E-flat)?
Is the time signature 4/4?
Are there four consecutive quarter notes all on the same pitch?
Are the articulations, in left-to-right order, staccatissimo, staccato, tenuto, then accent?
Are the articulation symbols placed above their respective notes, and are they labeled a), b), c), and d) above the staff?

prompt: Music theory drafting task: On a single five‑line staff in bass clef, notate the ascending one‑octave G‑flat major scale using whole notes and no key signature. Spell every pitch with correct diatonic/enharmonic names for this key (Gb, Ab, Bb, Cb, Db, Eb, F, Gb), placing accidentals before the notes rather than in the key signature. Keep the motion strictly stepwise and end on the octave above the starting Gb. You may place the note names beneath the staff.

scoring_points.question: Is there a single staff containing musical notation?
Is the clef a bass (F) clef?
Are all notes written as whole notes of equal duration?
Is there no key signature, with accidentals applied as needed before notes?
Are the eight pitches spelled in order as Gb–Ab–Bb–Cb–Db–Eb–F–Gb (correct enharmonic spellings for G-flat major)?
Does the melody proceed strictly by step in ascending order without skips?
Is the final Gb an exact octave above the initial Gb?
Do flats appear on Gb, Ab, Bb, Cb, Db, and Eb, with no accidental on F?
